children.subject: That's correct, there are only 10 seats reserved. Any seniors who need the class as a graduation requirement should Phase 1 the class and we will be sure to let them in. Reserve categories will expire once the adjustment period begins.

I just used my Phase 1 units for EE16A (I'm a rising senior) but I was put on the waitlist. I'm fine with being on the waitlist but my concern is with what Lab Section I get. If I'm on the waitlist now, will I know for sure that I should be able to get the Lab I'm also on the waitlist for? For context, I'm waitlisted for Lab Section 107 and on the guide it says that there's only an enrollment limit of 4 for that Lab Section. I'm assuming this is temporary and Lab 107 will be a regular lab size? 

Thank you!

There is no way to know for sure if you will get into the lab you want. You will need to closely monitor the seats in that lab. Lab 107 will eventually expand to a normal lab size but I can't let you know by how many seats as those seats are dependent on the number of CS scholars that enroll in that lab.

I see. That's unfortunate :/  Wouldn't that mean seniors will end up having to settle for 8am lab times while new admits will get more preferable lab section times? How come seniors don't get priority in this case?

I'm also a CS Senior trying to sign up for this class, and it won't even let me get on the waitlist (there is no waitlist option when I delete and re-add the class), I get this message : You are unable to enroll in this class at this time. Available seats are reserved and you do not meet the reserve capacity requirements. If a wait list is available, you may still be placed on the waitlist for this class... 
What should I do?
@Riya pick a different lab section. There's a chance that the lab you're trying to pick has a full waitlist and therefore you can't even add yourself onto the waitlist.
I just checked, all the labs are open but the discussion sections all seem to be closed?
Never mind, didn't see the 999 section. Thanks!
Same situation here...I don't think it's due to the lab section, but the reserved seats have been filled already?

It should still let you add to the waitlist regardless. I think even when I had my phase 1 the reserved seats were gone and that's why I got put on the waitlist. Check the Academic Guide for whether the waitlist is full for your section since it'll show up as Green on CalCentral since seats are still open but the waitlist is full (usually capped at 3) and that's the reason why you can't get on the waitlist.

I'm also a rising senior who Phase 1'ed EE16a. Am I correct in understanding that we'll only get off the waitlist after Phase 2 when the waitlist processes, and hope that our lab section does not get full?
To be fair you're technically "recommended/supposed to" take 16A and 16B freshmen year, but that's really unfortunate :/
16AB are lower division classes intended to be taken by freshmen/sophomore/incoming junior transfers. They serve as prereqs for many other courses, as a result we prioritize freshmen.
I am a senior and need this class to graduate, but I am not even given the option to waitlist myself and can not get into the class
Make sure you are adding DIS999.
Is there only 10 seats reserved for CS seniors for EE16a? Shouldn't there be more since it's their last year to graduate? Thanks!
Update: bug seems to have been fixed, very strange
If you run into this problem again, feel free to email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu and we will look into asap.

I see from last semester's enrollment information thread (@7800) that there was a bug in the system preventing some time conflict overrides, even when one of the classes is an EECS class. Does anyone know if that has been fixed yet? I am getting a similar error message to the anon in the previous thread, that is: 

"A scheduling conflict exists with a currently enrolled class 27796. The requested class is set to not allow any students to enroll in classes with time conflicts. Law students are ineligible for time conflict overrides."
At this time, we do not have plans to expand the class.
Will EECS 127 expand, or is the class size fixed? Thanks.
+1 i really want to take this class!
At this time, we do not have plans to expand the class but we will update Piazza if anything changes.
As per @9444, the system is not allowing enrollment, saying that there is no waitlist available. Is this the intended behavior? Classes.berkeley.edu currently has the waitlist at 25/40. Thanks!

If you are trying to add yourself to a lab/dis with a wait list that is already full, the system will not allow you to enroll.
If you continue having issues after trying to enroll in a section that has an open waitlist, please email me so that I can look into the issue.
Is EECS 106A likely to be expanded?
Email the instructor for more information.
what if the instructor doesn't reply and i can't find him at the office? (Prof. Umesh Vazirani)
I suggest attending the lecture and talking to the professor in person.
How do i get permission to enroll in CS 294?
See my response to your previous email.

So recently I got this email that I wasn't enrolled in EE 16A, but on CalCentral it shows that I am enrolled in all of the sections for the course. However, when I click the course I see that the I am on the waitlist for the lab section. Does this mean I have to re-enroll into EE 16A off the waitlist?

history.content:
Fall 2019 EE and EECS enrollment information:

Enrollment Priorities for EE16A and EE16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

EE 16A: See classes.berkeley.edu for the labs schedule. Some labs are split to have a total of 50 seats. For example, Lab 105/105A occur at the same time, day, and location. You may enroll in either.

  • EE16A discussion sections for transfer students will be announced during the first week of lecture.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EE16A and EE16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EE16A and EE16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: Dissimilar to the CS side, if you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

EE/EECS Enrollment Drop-In Hours:

will resume during the adjustment period, starting August 19th in 205 Cory

Week of 9/16-9/20:

Monday: 1-4pm

Tuesday: available through email only

Wednesday: available through email only

Thursday: 1-4pm

Friday: 1-4pm

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.

will resume during the adjustment period, starting August 19th in 205 Cory

history.subject: EE/EECS, Fall 19 Enrollment Information

history.content:
Fall 2019 EE and EECS enrollment information:

Enrollment Priorities for EE16A and EE16B have been updated and can be viewed on the classes.berkeley.edu website. At this time, we do not have plans to expand either class but we will update this post as we receive more information.

  • If either one of these classes are required for you to graduate, we recommend you use Phase 1.

  • Once everyone has had their Phase 2 appointment, there will be no more enrollment priorities and the waitlist will process in order. If your lab fills while you’re waitlisted, the only way to switch it is to drop and re-add the class. This will put you at the bottom of the WL, but you cannot be enrolled into a full section. WL’d students with full labs will be skipped over when the WL processes automatically. Check classes.berkeley.edu for open labs before dropping and re-adding.

EE and EECS upper-division classes: These classes do not have enrollment priorities.

EE 16A: See classes.berkeley.edu for the labs schedule. Some labs are split to have a total of 50 seats. For example, Lab 105/105A occur at the same time, day, and location. You may enroll in either.

  • EE16A discussion sections for transfer students will be announced during the first week of lecture.

999 DIS Sections: Similarly to the CS side, EE16A and EE16B will have 999 discussion sections to facilitate enrollment. For EE16A and EE16B, you may be enrolled in one discussion section, but attend a different one. When adding this class you should choose the lecture, a lab section, and DIS 999. The schedules of DIS sections are visible on classes.berkeley.edu. You may attend any DIS section as long as there is a seat in the classroom. If the class is full, you will need to attend a different section. You must attend the lab section in which you are enrolled.

Switching Secondary Sections while Waitlisted: Dissimilar to the CS side, if you need to switch to another lab and/or dis section while waitlisted for an EE/EECS class, you still need to drop the class completely and re-add in order to switch.

  • If you are enrolled in a class, you should use the “Edit” feature in CalCentral to switch. Note if you choose a full secondary section, you will be bumped to the waitlist as you can only be enrolled into open sections.

Time Conflicts: The enrollment system will allow time conflicts between EE and EECS courses with other classes. It is still your responsibility to adhere to class attendance policies and check with the professor of the class regarding alternate midterm and final exam dates.

Enrollment Tips:

There must be an open seat in all parts of the class and you must meet enrollment priorities, if any, at the time of adding the class to be enrolled. E.g., if the class has lecture + lab + discussion, you have to be able to enroll in all 3 to be officially enrolled.

  • Unit limits: Phase I = 13.5 units, Phase II = 17.5, Adjustment Period = 20.5 These include waitlisted classes.

Q: I am waitlisted and my position went higher on the list, e.g. from 4 to 5. Why did this happen?

A: This is most likely due to an enrolled student switching from an open lab/discussion to a lab/discussion that is full. Since you cannot enroll into a full section, the enrolled student is bumped down to the waitlist at position #1, which shifts everyone down one. This is normal. If you see yourself, however, suddenly shift down many seats at once, this could be a bug. Please email ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu if you suddenly see yourself shift 10+ seats at once.

 

Enrollment FAQs:

See https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

For questions on EE/EECS enrollment, email at ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu.
